III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge Planning
Section (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of the
Description following information shall be documented in the case record
within 14 days after discharge:
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was discharged from facility with items that were
confiscated upon their arrival at the facility due to the items being
safety hazards. The youth has a history of self-harm and these
items went against a safety plan created by the facility to keep
youth safe. Foster parents were not made aware that youth was
discharged with these items and the youth self-harmed.
Investigation Foster Parent 1/Complaint Source and Foster Parent 2 were
interviewed via phone on February 1, 2023. Foster Parent 1
and Foster Parent 2 were interviewed together via a phone
conference. Foster Parent 1 reported Youth A had lived with them
before entering the facility for a short period and re-entered their
home on January 3, 2023. Foster Parent 1 reported she picked up
Youth A from the facility to discharge and met with Therapist on
the day of discharge. She reported the foster care worker was not
present at the facility. On the day of discharge, Foster Parent 1
reported the facility returned all of Youth A’s items to him and
reported Youth A’s items filled up the entirety of the car. She
reported Therapist did provide an inventory list of all the items that
were packed up for Youth A and Foster Parent 1 reported she did
not personally go through that list. She reported while in the car
Youth A stated the facility gave him back three pencil sharpeners
and Youth A handed them over to Foster Parent 1. She reported
she has major concerns that contraband items were given back to
Youth A from the facility, and she was not made aware of it.
Foster Parent 1 reported the foster parents have been working
with Therapist and Youth A for three months before discharge and
Youth A had been self-harm free for those three months. Foster
Parent 1 reported they completed family therapy with Therapist,
2

completed a test overnight trial for 6 days, and created a safety
plan jointly. Foster Parent 1 reported the safety plan included
Youth A could not have access to razor blades or pencil
sharpeners because that is how he self-harm. She reported she
asked Therapist if kitchen knives and scissors should be locked
up and Therapist stated it did not. Foster Parent 1 reported after a
couple of weeks of concerning self-harm behaviors she knew she
had to lock those things up. It was reported there was one time
Youth A got a hold of kitchen scissors in the home and used them
to self-harm. Youth A also tried to break a glass candle holder that
he have received back from the facility to try to self-harm. Foster
Parent 1 reported all the razors, knives, and pencil sharpeners
were locked up in the home because the razors and pencil
sharpeners are what Youth A used in the facility to self-harm.
Foster Parent 2 noted all the self-harm behavior Youth A
conducted within their home were from items the facility provided
back to him besides the attempt with the kitchen scissors and a
soda can. She reported there were also broken DVDs, pens that
were broken, and broken plexiglass that were given back that
Youth A would self-harm with as well. Foster Parent 1 reported
she was aware that items were taken away from Youth A due to
self-harm at the facility but were not aware it was going to be
returned and that it was given back to Youth A. She reported
Youth A had access to their items before Foster Parent 1 got to
the facility as the facility had items back up upon arrival.
Youth A was interviewed via phone on February 2, 2023, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 2. Youth A reported he was
at the facility for about eight months before discharging to Foster
Parent 1 on January 3, 2023. He reported Foster Parent 1 picked
him up from the facility and Therapist helped with this transition.
Youth A reported that all his personal items were given back to
him at the time of discharge. He reported he told Foster Parent 1
in front of Therapist he had pencil sharpeners and wanted to be
truthful about having them. Youth A reported Foster Parent 1
asked for those items once they got into the car. He reported
when he got to the foster home he started going through his items
from the facility and within his room and found broken CDs, pens,
pencil sharpeners, and other sharps. Youth A reported he gave
those items to Foster Parent 2. When asked how Youth A had
those items at the facility, he reported he had them within his
bedroom and some of those items he was allowed to have, such
as pens and pencils. He reported some of the items he did hide in
his room since he was not allowed to have them such as the
pencil sharpeners, which he got from off-grounds school. Youth A
reported he was given his contraband items back from the facility
3

by Therapist and Supervisor. He reported one of the contraband
items was the cords and Supervisor gave that back to him. Youth
A reported the “contraband items” were not items he has a history
of harming himself with and were just a rule he could not have at
the facility, such as his charging cords. He reported Staff 1 packed
up his items from his bedroom on discharge day. Youth A reported
before discharging he worked with Therapist and foster parents on
a transition plan. He reported they came up together with creating
a safety plan as a team.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1.
Therapist reported she was present and assisted with Youth A’s
discharge when Foster Parent 1 arrived on January 3, 2023. She
reported the only items that were actual contraband items from the
facility that were returned to Youth A was two inappropriate books
and Youth A’s wallet. Therapist reported Youth A was never given
back any pencil sharpeners and noted all pencil sharpeners from
the craft kits were taken out and thrown away. Youth A also did
not have any CDs or DVDs and any items that Youth A attempted
to harm himself with at the facility were thrown away such as any
broken plastic items or glass. Therapist reported she does not
remember Youth A talking about or handing over pencil
sharpeners to Foster Parent 1. She reported Foster Parent 1 was
given the inventory list which was all the items of Youth A that
were returned and that was signed by all parties. Therapist
reported Youth A was self-harm free for at least three months
before discharge and the only items restricted from Youth A were
razors and pencil sharpeners due to the blade. She reported
Youth A was allowed to have pens and colored pencils. Youth A
did have a history of hiding items on his body that he would self-
harm with such as getting pencil sharpeners from school and
hiding it within his bra. Therapist reported she worked with the
foster parents and Youth A on a transition plan for three months
before discharge and assisted with weekly family therapy. She
reported a discharge report was completed and signed on the day
of Youth A’s discharge by Youth A, Foster Parent 1, and
Therapist. She reported she completed a safety plan with foster
parents and Youth A in collaboration before discharge and
everyone agreed upon it. Therapist reported the facility is also
providing aftercare services to the family since discharge
occurred.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on
February 2, 2023, in collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1.
Supervisor reported he was present when Youth A was being
4

discharged from the facility on January 3, 2023, to Foster Parent
1. He reported Youth A was given all his items back from the
facility that was either within their room or within storage.
Supervisor 1 reported there were no items returned to Youth A
that he attempted to harm himself with when he was at the facility,
such as broken plastic, pencil sharpeners, and glass because
those were all disposed of at the facility. At the time of discharge,
Youth A had been self-harm free for at least three months and
was allowed to have pens and pencils within their room. He
reported the items Youth A was not allowed to have were pencil
sharpeners and razors due to his history. Supervisor reported he
did not see or hear about Youth A handing over pencil sharpeners
to Foster Parent 1 at the facility. He reported Youth A was given
back some charging cords and an extension cord that was in his
storage box and that was all labeled within the clothing inventory.
He reported Youth A had no history of strangling himself with
those cords.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on February 22, 2023, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Staff 1 reported he was
originally tasked with helping Youth A pack up his things for
discharge, but Staff 2 completed that task. He reported he did
move the boxes that were packed up out of Youth A’s room into
the staff office for discharge. Staff 1 reported there were no
contraband items packed up that he saw.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on February 23, 2023, in
collaboration with MDHHS Worker 1. Staff 2 reported she
assisted Youth A with packing his items for discharge. She
reported Youth A had been self-harm free for a couple of months
before discharge and was allowed to have their art supplies,
besides the pencil sharpeners. Staff 2 reported she did not pack
up any broken DVDs/CDs or broken plexiglass. She reported if
she saw those items, she would have been thrown out.
Conference call was held with MDHHS Worker 1 on March 1,
2023. MDHHS worker 1 reported there are no findings to their
investigation.
Documentation:
- Youth A’s Safety Plan from the facility to the foster
home- This safety plan details Youth A’s triggers, warning
signs, coping skills, home rules, expectations, and safety
planning. Within the safety planning section, it notes Youth
A’s shaving razors will be locked up and given only when
showering and the razor will be returned to the foster
5

parents after the shower. The safety plan also notes all
medications will be locked up. This safety plan was agreed
upon by the facility, youth, foster parents, and foster care
team who all received a copy.
- Youth A’s Discharge report from the facility dated
January 3, 2023- Therapist completed this report noting
Youth A had made positive progress at the facility and is
noted to be safe and suitable to move into Foster Parent 1
and Foster Parent 2’s home. Youth A was able to complete
visits with the foster parents and engaged in family therapy
conducted by Therapist prior to transitioning into the home.
Therapist noted Youth A has had no concerns with suicidal
plans/ intent, physical aggression, or self-harm before
discharge. Youth A denied any feelings of depression upon
discharge and denied suicidal ideation and self-harm urges.
Recommended services after discharge recommended for
Youth A to continue receiving mental health services
consisting of individual counseling, family counseling as
needed, and medication management; participate in any
community group opportunities for his age group in which
he is interested and appropriate for, continue to receive
medical and dental care; continue to follow any
recommendations made by MDHHS. One of the goals
noted by Therapist was for Youth A to help create and
follow the safety plan put in place while in the foster
parent’s home. Youth A, Therapist, and Foster Parent 1
signed this discharge report.
- Residential Updated Service Plan dated 12/14/22-
Therapist completed an updated service plan for Youth A
during the reporting period of 10/26/22-12/14/2022. Within
this report, it was noted Youth A had zero instances of self-
harm during the reporting period and was not restricted to
any items. Therapist reported the planning that was
completed with the foster parents for a healthy transition
included family therapy on weekly basis starting November
23, 2023.
- Discharge Clothing inventory checklist for Youth A
dated 01/3/2023- This was the discharge inventory list
noting all the items that were packed up and returned to
Youth A from the facility upon discharge. This was signed
by Therapist, Foster Parent 1, and Youth A on the date of
discharge. The inventory list noted: clothing, stuffed
animals, stickers, headphones, a massage gun, a box of
6

electronic cords, family pictures, notes books, books,
picture frames, blankets, a box of fidgets, crafts, a makeup
kit, art kit, coloring book, sketch books, canvas, and
puzzles. The inventory list does not list any CDs, DVDs,
broken plexiglass, or glass candle holders.
- Maple Lodge Contraband List- This is a list of items
posted within the staff office noting the items the youth at
the facility cannot have. Some items noted on this list were:
candles, extension cords, mature topic books, razors, razor
blades, pencil sharpers, broken items-sharps, broken
shards of glass/metal, DVD/CD (certain items may be
allowed when used to teach-though no independent use).
Youth A did have a box filled with cords and given upon
discharge that was noted to be in a storage part of the
building and released to the foster family upon discharge.
- Residential Aftercare Report dated February 1, 2023-
The facility has been providing ongoing aftercare support to
Youth A and his foster family. There were no reported
concerns of contraband given to Youth A from the facility
noted within this report.
- HR file and Training Log for Supervisor- Supervisor has
no disciplinary actions noted within his HR file. Supervisor
is up to date on all required training.
- HR file and Training Log for Therapist- Therapist has no
disciplinary actions noted within his HR file for child safety.
Therapist is up to date on all required training.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance with the discharge plan for
Youth A. The facility provided the foster family with an inventory
list of items that were packed and returned to Youth A. Within that
inventory list there were no listed items of DVDs/ CDs or broken
pens or broken plexiglass. It did note on the inventory list that
there were craft kits that could have included pens, but this was
not a prohibited item for Youth A. Within Youth A’s interview he
reported he would get items to self-harm such as pencil
sharpeners and items to break to self-harm from off ground school
and would hide items on his body to store in his room without staff
knowing. The foster parents reported concerns the facility
provided items used to self-harm but did not go through Youth A’s
discharge items when returning to their home. The facility reported
they did not provide Youth A with any items such as DVDs, CDs,
broke pens or broken plexiglass as if those items were found it
would have been thrown out. It is believed the facility did not
provide these items and the items could have been already within
the home or from Youth A hiding them from the facility and foster
7

parents. The facility had worked with the family three months
before discharge, completed their discharge report and signed by
foster parents, and provided aftercare services for support.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
